awd_titl_txt: Understanding and Enhancing Self Regulated Learning in Introductory Computer Science Courses
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education Program: Education and Human Resources (IUSE: EHR), this project aims to serve the national interest in high-quality computer science education.  Given the dramatic growth in computing-related educational programs, it is important to improve student learning outcomes in introductory computer science courses. Self-regulated learning may be a key to achieving this goal.  Self-regulated learning includes the abilities of learners to set their own goals, monitor the own learning, and adjust learning strategies as needed.  Research studies show that many computer science students have poor self-regulated learning abilities.  As a result, they engage in behaviors that interfere with learning, such as procrastination and skipping content.  This project seeks to help computer science educators and researchers understand and enhance students' self-regulated learning abilities. The project will examine  the relationship between students' increased use of self-regulated learning strategies and their performance in introductory computer science courses.  It is expected that students who develop skills in self-regulated learning will be more successful in introductory computer science courses and persist into computer science majors and careers.  The project thus has the potential to broader participation within computer science fields.

This project will focus on the self-regulated learning that emerges at the intersection of two types of activities: reviewing conceptual materials during programming and trying out ideas through writing programs. The conceptual materials, online textbook, and programming Integrated Development Environment from an introductory computer science course will be instrumented to record all student interactions.  For example, it will record when a student completes interactive exercises or how a student refers to the text when completing a programming problem. The collected data will be used to better understand self-regulated learning by modeling patterns of use of individual materials and patterns of use across the different materials. The project will also examine how these behaviors map to students' development of self-regulated learning, as well as self-efficacy and confidence, and how each of these constructs predicts the development of computer science knowledge and skills across the course. It will also study how the developments in self-regulated learning, confidence, metacognition,  programming skills, and computer science conceptual knowledge are associated with students' longer-term interest in computer science. In doing so, the project will attempt both to understand the factors that lead to greater success in computer science and retention in the computer science pipeline, and to develop theoretical knowledge about the development of self-regulated learning. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA, THE

por.por_cntn:
Project Summary:

This NSF grant funded a four-year research project investigating self-regulated learning (SRL) in introductory computer science (CS) courses. Our goal was to study and scaffold the self-regulated learning that emerges at the intersection of two types of activities: reviewing conceptual materials during programming and trying out ideas through programs, ultimately improving course success and fostering long-term engagement with CS.

Intellectual Merit:

Our research yielded significant insights into SRL in introductory CS:

  • Identified key SRL strategies: We discovered that a majority of students engage in voluntary practice. However, students were more likely to engage in voluntary practice if they had higher prior performance, and students who procrastinated were less likely to engage in voluntary practice. We found that engaging in voluntary practice did not have a significant impact on course performance. We confirmed that a majority of novice programmers lack the metacognitive knowledge and skills to harness the benefits of self-regulated learning needed to solve open-ended programming problems.  Our results showed a reversal of the “hard-easy effect”: in our case, novices tended to underplace themselves on harder tasks, yet overplace themselves on easier ones. Furthermore, underplacers performed better on an exam compared to overplacers.

 

  • Unearthed challenges specific to CS: We found that the abstract nature of CS concepts, the complex syntax of programming languages, and the iterative nature of debugging create unique SRL challenges, that can be mitigated via adequate help-seeking strategies. We found that students with more prior knowledge sought more help on online Q&A platforms compared to students with less prior knowledge. Our project helped disentangle and understand two related but different concepts: active listening – an effective regulation of learning strategy where CS students delay starting an assignment to seek help (on Q&A platforms) –  that is beneficial to code quality, and procrastination – a maladaptive approach to regulation of learning.    

  • Demonstrated the effectiveness of targeted interventions: We designed and tested a single email nudge intervention and found that it did not have an impact on procrastination and learning performance. However, it improved students’ persistence in working on programming assignments.

Broader Impacts:

Our project led to significant broader impacts:

  • Improved CS instruction and Empowered students: Our work contributed to fostering a more student-centered approach to CS education, by providing CS educators actionable items that they can deploy in the classroom to equip students with the SRL skills they need to succeed not only in CS but also in other academic and professional pursuits. 

Outcomes and Significance:

Our research has demonstrated significant intellectual merit and broader impacts within CS education. We have gained more in-depth understanding of how students self-regulate their learning in introductory CS, identified the challenges they face, and have developed effective interventions to overcome some of those challenges. Our findings have the potential for lasting impact on CS classrooms, empowering students and improving their chances of success in this essential field.

Looking Forward:

The success of this project motivates us to continue our research on SRL in CS education. We aim to explore metacognition and help-seeking deeper, to develop personalized SRL support systems for students. We believe that by supporting learners in becoming self-regulated, we can create a more inclusive and accessible CS education landscape for all.


Last Modified: 01/30/2024
Modified by: Eric N Fouh Mbindi

Project Summary:


This NSF grant funded a four-year research project investigating self-regulated learning (SRL) in introductory computer science (CS) courses. Our goal was to study and scaffold the self-regulated learning that emerges at the intersection of two types of activities: reviewing conceptual materials during programming and trying out ideas through programs, ultimately improving course success and fostering long-term engagement with CS.


Intellectual Merit:


Our research yielded significant insights into SRL in introductory CS:




Identified key SRL strategies: We discovered that a majority of students engage in voluntary practice. However, students were more likely to engage in voluntary practice if they had higher prior performance, and students who procrastinated were less likely to engage in voluntary practice. We found that engaging in voluntary practice did not have a significant impact on course performance. We confirmed that a majority of novice programmers lack the metacognitive knowledge and skills to harness the benefits of self-regulated learning needed to solve open-ended programming problems. Our results showed a reversal of the hard-easy effect: in our case, novices tended to underplace themselves on harder tasks, yet overplace themselves on easier ones. Furthermore, underplacers performed better on an exam compared to overplacers.




 




Unearthed challenges specific to CS: We found that the abstract nature of CS concepts, the complex syntax of programming languages, and the iterative nature of debugging create unique SRL challenges, that can be mitigated via adequate help-seeking strategies. We found that students with more prior knowledge sought more help on online Q&A platforms compared to students with less prior knowledge. Our project helped disentangle and understand two related but different concepts: active listening  an effective regulation of learning strategy where CS students delay starting an assignment to seek help (on Q&A platforms)  that is beneficial to code quality, and procrastination  a maladaptive approach to regulation of learning.                




Demonstrated the effectiveness of targeted interventions: We designed and tested a single email nudge intervention and found that it did not have an impact on procrastination and learning performance. However, it improved students persistence in working on programming assignments.




Broader Impacts:


Our project led to significant broader impacts:




Improved CS instruction and Empowered students: Our work contributed to fostering a more student-centered approach to CS education, by providing CS educators actionable items that they can deploy in the classroom to equip students with the SRL skills they need to succeed not only in CS but also in other academic and professional pursuits.




Outcomes and Significance:


Our research has demonstrated significant intellectual merit and broader impacts within CS education. We have gained more in-depth understanding of how students self-regulate their learning in introductory CS, identified the challenges they face, and have developed effective interventions to overcome some of those challenges. Our findings have the potential for lasting impact on CS classrooms, empowering students and improving their chances of success in this essential field.


Looking Forward:


The success of this project motivates us to continue our research on SRL in CS education. We aim to explore metacognition and help-seeking deeper, to develop personalized SRL support systems for students. We believe that by supporting learners in becoming self-regulated, we can create a more inclusive and accessible CS education landscape for all.					Last Modified: 01/30/2024
